section.name: HEALTH CARE OF CHILDBEARING WOMEN, THEORY

comments:
The Health Care of Childbearing Women (Antepartum) course builds upon the content of the Well Women Health Care course and the Fetal Evaluation course.  The focus is advanced clinical management of prenatal care for the childbearing family. Conceptual threads of public policy and ethics are integrated within the content to help students to identify broader implications for prenatal care.  Content includes theory and practice related to nurse-midwifery management of the normal pregnant woman, and nurse-midwifery/nurse practitioner management and strategies to reduce selected obstetric complications.

Students praised the course’s content, calling it a “great course” and saying that they “learned a lot of information that was used in the clinical setting.”  However, some students felt that there was too little emphasis certain areas of care, and the style of learning was “assumed” to be against the use of PowerPoints.

Students lauded Jurgaitis’s lectures and passion as a speaker.

Overall students indicated that they did “a lot of work, but I also learned a lot.”  Though several students mentioned the BlackBoard website as being disorganized, the main complaint was the relatively dense nature of the readings for the class.  However, most students would recommend the class to other advanced nursing students.

section.name: HEALTH CARE OF CHILDBEARING WOMEN, THEORY

comments:
This course, entitled Healthcare and Theory of Childbearing Women, builds upon the well-woman health care course.  The focus is management of prenatal care for the childbearing family.  Conceptual threads of public policy and ethics are integrated within the content to help students to identify broader implications for prenatal care.  Content includes theory and practice related to nurse-midwifery/ nurse practitioner management of the normal pregnant woman, and nurse-midwifery/ nurse practitioner management and strategies to reduce selected obstetric complications.
	Students generally enjoyed this class, though many felt frustrated with the structure and priorities of the course.  Many felt that certain topics should have been given more or less attention, and that the objectives of the class were misleading in terms of what the class actually covered.  Overall, the course was seen as “great” and “informational,” but with “room for improvement.”  Students stressed the lack of class material presented online and the lack of lectures on diabetes and cardiac care as their faults with the class.
	This course was led by Dr. Lewis along with numerous guest lecturers.  Lewis was seen as favorable and the lecturers were “experienced” and “very good.” However, each guest lecturer brought his or her own teaching style, which didn’t necessarily mesh with the style of the course.
	This course requires an intensive time commitment from the students, as case studies and assignments require a lot of time preparing outside of class.  Students lamented the absence of feedback on assignments but referred to the class as an overall “great course.”  Prerequisites for the course are NURS 781 and 782, with a corequisite of NURS 784.
